questions.article:
The following text is from Darcie Little Badger’s 2021 novel A Snake Falls to Earth. Nina is looking at old family photographs.

Nina couldn’t stop looking at the sepia-toned photograph in an oak frame. Propped on the window ledge, it featured a portrait of Great-Great-Grandmother Rosita as a young woman.

©2021 by Darcie Little Badger
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word “featured” most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: ignored

options.name: B
options.content: approved

options.name: C
options.content: questioned

options.name: D
options.content: displayed

questions.correct: displayed

questions.article:
The following text is from Mark Twain's 1876 novel The Adventures of Tom Sawyer. Tom, a child, has been told by his aunt to paint their house's fence.

Tom appeared on the sidewalk with a bucket of whitewash and a long-handled brush. He surveyed the fence, and all gladness left him and a deep melancholy settled down upon his spirit. Thirty yards of board fence nine feet high.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word “surveyed” most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: Examined

options.name: B
options.content: Adjusted

options.name: C
options.content: Organized

options.name: D
options.content: Complimented

questions.correct: Examined

questions.article: Politicians routinely claim that journalists are ______, but while it's true that some journalists allow their own views to creep into their reporting more than others do, most journalists make a good-faith effort to be neutral in their reporting.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: sensitive

options.name: B
options.content: biased

options.name: C
options.content: misinformed

options.name: D
options.content: irrelevant

questions.correct: biased

questions.article: The Sungai Mahakam River delta system is located in Indonesia, where the river drains into the Makassar Strait, and is shaped by ______ factors: for example, the geography of the coastline influences sedimentary deposition, which over time alters coastal geography.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: interdependent

options.name: B
options.content: unyielding

options.name: C
options.content: tenuous

options.name: D
options.content: comprehensive

questions.correct: interdependent

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from Jason Reynolds’s 2016 novel Ghost. The narrator, who is in middle school, is at a bus stop.

Just go there [to the bus stop] to look at the people working out. See, the gym across the street has this big window—like the whole wall is a window—and they have those machines that make you feel like you walking up steps and so everybody just be facing the bus stop, looking all crazy like they’re about to pass out. And trust me, there ain’t nothing funnier than that. So I check that out for a little while like it’s some kind of movie: The about to Pass Out Show, starring stair-stepper person one through ten.

©2016 by Jason Reynolds
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To discuss a movie that the narrator saw in a theater.

options.name: B
options.content: To give a reason why the narrator is excited to start middle school.

options.name: C
options.content: To describe an activity that the narrator finds amusing.

options.name: D
options.content: To explain a problem that the narrator has overcome.

questions.correct: To describe an activity that the narrator finds amusing.

questions.article: In 1889, Ferdinand L. Barnett founded Omaha, Nebraska's first Black newspaper, The Progress. Barnett's accomplishment is just one example of the rich history of Black journalism in the United States. That history is preserved by the National Association of Black Journalists, which was founded in Washington, DC, in 1975 to support Black media professionals and honor people like Barnett.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence?

options.name: A
options.content: It emphasizes the challenges that the National Association of Black Journalists has overcome.

options.name: B
options.content: It highlights several important members of the National Association of Black Journalists.

options.name: C
options.content: It lists the achievements of the National Association of Black Journalists.

options.name: D
options.content: It summarizes the purpose of founding the National Association of Black Journalists.

questions.correct: It summarizes the purpose of founding the National Association of Black Journalists.

questions.article: Cats and toads see in three dimensions (3D) by combining two images in their brains, one from each eye. This produces a sense of depth, helping the animals judge how close or far away an object is. Researchers have investigated 3D vision in praying mantises as well. In one study, Vivek Nityãnanda and his team fitted mantises' faces with two different color filters, one covering each eye, much like the filters in 3D glasses once worn at movies. By observing the mantises' reaction to projected images, the team confirmed that mantises do indeed have 3D vision, but it's unlike that of other animals.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: The text explains the general differences between the vision of cats and toads, then introduces a study of praying mantises' vision.

options.name: B
options.content: The text discusses 3D vision in cats and toads, then introduces a study about this kind of vision in praying mantises.

options.name: C
options.content: The text reviews the similarities in how cats and toads see, then provides details of a study about praying mantises to confirm these similarities.

options.name: D
options.content: The text describes how cats and toads see, then presents a study about praying mantises that challenges the accuracy of that description.

questions.correct: The text discusses 3D vision in cats and toads, then introduces a study about this kind of vision in praying mantises.

questions.article: “Cocoa” is one example of an English word that has an Indigenous origin. The word came to English indirectly from cacao, the Spanish word for the plant that chocolate is made from. Spanish had borrowed it from Nahuatl, an Indigenous language of Central Mexico, in which the word's original form is cacahuatl. “Alpaca” also has an Indigenous origin and entered English through Spanish. But in this case, the original source was Quechua, a language of South America, in which the word for the woolly farm animal is allpaqa.
questions.question: According to the text, what is one difference between the English words “cocoa” and “alpaca”?

options.name: A
options.content: “Cocoa” entered English recently, but “alpaca” entered English many centuries ago.

options.name: B
options.content: “Cocoa” can be traced to the Nahuatl language, while “alpaca” can be traced to the Quechua language.

options.name: C
options.content: “Cocoa” changed in meaning significantly when English borrowed the word from Spanish, whereas “alpaca” retained its original meaning.

options.name: D
options.content: “Cocoa” is known for being Indigenous in origin, while “alpaca” is mistakenly regarded as Spanish in origin.

questions.correct: “Cocoa” can be traced to the Nahuatl language, while “alpaca” can be traced to the Quechua language.

questions.article: In present-day Chiapas, Mexico, archaeologist Robert Rosenswig, remote-sensing specialist Ricardo Lopez-Torrijos, and colleagues have located 41 smaller settlements surrounding the ancient Mesoamerican city of Izapa. The researchers have concluded that these settlements were culturally linked to Izapa because each of the settlements is the same age and configured in the same manner as Izapa, with a pyramid to the north and a plaza to the south. Their shared structural orientation suggests that residents of the settlements likely performed some of the same cultural ceremonies as residents in Izapa did.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: Researchers have inferred that Izapa was related to the smaller settlements that surrounded it based in part on the similarity of their construction.

options.name: B
options.content: Researchers have determined that the arrangement of Izapa's structures was based on those of other nearby settlements.

options.name: C
options.content: Although archaeologists have learned much about Izapa over years of research, they have only recently found the smaller settlements that surrounded it.

options.name: D
options.content: Cultural ceremonies in lzapa seem to have played a more important role for its residents than those in smaller surrounding settlement did.

questions.correct: Researchers have inferred that Izapa was related to the smaller settlements that surrounded it based in part on the similarity of their construction.

questions.article: Many films in a language other than English grow to be financially successful over the course of their time in movie theaters in the United States, but some become immediate successes in their opening weekends. Such success is driven by many factors like advertising, genre popularity, and the fame of the actors and directors. A student claims that opening weekend earnings can reliably predict whether a film will be nominated for an Oscar: films that draw large audiences at the beginning of their release are the most likely contenders to earn these coveted award nominations.
questions.question: Which choice best describes data from the table that weaken the student's claim?

options.name: A
options.content: The Girl Who Played with Fire was not recognized by the Oscars but had much higher opening weekend earnings than Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, which was recognized by the Oscars.

options.name: B
options.content: Although both Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and Eat Drink Man Woman were recognized by the Oscars, Crouching Tiger: Hidden Dragon had higher lifetime earnings.

options.name: C
options.content: Iron Monkey had higher lifetime earnings than Eat Drink Man Woman did, even though Eat Drink Man Woman was recognized by the Oscars.

options.name: D
options.content: Although both Iron Monkey and The Girl Who Played with Fire were directed by well-known figures, neither film was recognized by the Oscars.

questions.correct: The Girl Who Played with Fire was not recognized by the Oscars but had much higher opening weekend earnings than Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, which was recognized by the Oscars.

questions.article:
Numbers of the 23 Non-native Tree Species Reported and the Insect and Fungus Threats to Them

Elisabeth Pötzelsberger and colleagues gathered data on 23 non-native tree species grown in Europe. They analyzed reports from Great Britain, Bulgaria, and Belgium about the number of these species grown in those countries as well as the numbers of insect and fungus species that damage those trees. The researchers concluded that in only one of these countries are there more insect species than fungus species that pose risks to these trees.
questions.question: Which choice best describes data from the table that support Pötzelsberger and colleagues' conclusion?

options.name: A
options.content: Great Britain and Belgium both reported fewer damaging insect species than damaging fungus species, whereas Bulgaria reported 16 fungus species and only 9 insect species.

options.name: B
options.content: Great Britain reported 290 damaging fungus species, which is a greater number of them than either Bulgaria or Belgium reported.

options.name: C
options.content: Bulgaria reported 14 damaging fungus species and 16 damaging insect species, while both Great Britain and Belgium reported a greater number of damaging fungus species than insect species.

options.name: D
options.content: Great Britain reported 290 damaging fungus species, whereas Belgium reported 11 damaging insect species.

questions.correct: Bulgaria reported 14 damaging fungus species and 16 damaging insect species, while both Great Britain and Belgium reported a greater number of damaging fungus species than insect species.

questions.article: To understand the extent of deforestation in the Chorotega Region of Costa Rica, Juan Pablo Arroyo-Mora and colleagues used aerial photography and remote sensing data to track changes in the forest cover area across different land use capability class (categories that indicate possible uses of forest land.) Due to the Chorotega region’s accessibility, various types of forest areas were converted to cattle practices as rising international meat prices drove a cattle ranching boom in the 1960s and 1970s. By the mid 1980s, however, increased public awareness and environmental reforms, along with a decline in meat prices, engendered a natural forest regrowth, as is evident by the ________
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the graph to complete the assertion?

options.name: A
options.content: decrease in the forest cover area for all classes from 1960 to 1979.

options.name: B
options.content: difference between the forest cover area in Class I-IV and in Class VIII2000.

options.name: C
options.content: similarity in forest cover area in Class I-IV and Class VIII in 1986.

options.name: D
options.content: increase in the forest cover area for all classes from 1979 to 2000.

questions.correct: increase in the forest cover area for all classes from 1979 to 2000.

questions.article: In countries with right-hand traffic, drivers who want to make a left turn at a traffic intersection with stoplights have to wait for either a gap in oncoming traffic or a designated left-turn signal to turn green. At busy intersections, this often causes a backup of vehicles waiting to turn left or being prevented from proceeding by left-turning vehicles in front of them. Transportation researcher Vikash V. Gayah claims that in urban areas eliminating the option to turn left at busy intersections—both with and without dedicated left-turn signals—would improve traffic flow and, as a result, reduce overall travel times even if such a restriction would require drivers to sometimes travel a slightly longer distance.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support the researcher's claim?

options.name: A
options.content: After a city eliminated left turns at busy intersections, a package delivery company reports that its drivers have been able to reach more addresses in the city daily, on average, and therefore deliver more packages there annually.

options.name: B
options.content: In a town that installed left-turn signals at all busy intersections, seven out of ten survey respondents agreed with the statement "the streets in my community are easier to navigate by motor vehicle than before.”

options.name: C
options.content: A traffic study of intersections in a large city shows that on average drivers wait longer to make a left turn at intersections without left-turn signals than at intersections with such signals.

options.name: D
options.content: Statistics reveal that school buses in a city that eliminated left turns at most intersections took on average two minutes longer to complete their routes after the restriction took effect than they did before.

questions.correct: After a city eliminated left turns at busy intersections, a package delivery company reports that its drivers have been able to reach more addresses in the city daily, on average, and therefore deliver more packages there annually.

questions.article: It is common for freshwater lakes near or above a latitude of 45° north of the equator, like Lake Stechlin in Germany, to accumulate surface ice in winter. A study from 1980 to 2006 showed that, in general, the number of days per winter that such lakes have measurable amounts of surface ice is declining. However, a researcher claimed that some lakes have instead seen an increase in the duration of ice.
questions.question: Which choice best describes data in the table that support the researcher's claim?

options.name: A
options.content: Lake Baikal had fewer days of ice in the winter of 1980-81 than it did in the winter of 2005-06.

options.name: B
options.content: Kitusjärvi is at a higher latitude than Mirror Lake and typically had more days of ice per winter than Mirror Lake did.

options.name: C
options.content: Kitusjärvi had more days of ice in the winter of 1980 81 than it did in the winter of 2005-06.

options.name: D
options.content: Kitusjärvi is at a higher latitude than Mirror Lake and typically had fewer days of ice per winter than Mirror Lake did.

questions.correct: Lake Baikal had fewer days of ice in the winter of 1980-81 than it did in the winter of 2005-06.

questions.article: The state of Colorado has designated the rusty crayfish as an invasive species that could outcompete some of the state's native species. Many other states draw similar distinctions between invasive and native species. But researchers Alejandro Camacho and Jason McLachlan have pointed out that Earth's climate is changing in ways that challenge such designations. Climate changes may cause animals to leave their current ranges and establish new ones. Climate changes may also create good habitats in areas where a species couldn't live previously. These observations suggest that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: Colorado was previously home to some rusty crayfish but they were outcompeted by invading species.

options.name: B
options.content: States such as Colorado may need to reevaluate their classifications of species.

options.name: C
options.content: Colorado should coordinate with other states to protect their native species from invasive species.

options.name: D
options.content: It's useful at present for Colorado to distinguish between invasive and native species in some instances but not in the case of the rusty crayfish.

questions.correct: States such as Colorado may need to reevaluate their classifications of species.

questions.article: To coders like Black Girls Code founder Kimberly Bryant, the computer programming languages Java and BASIC have a clear difference: the former is an object-oriented language while the latter is not. Because both languages require highly technical knowledge to understand, though, laypeople ______ to distinguish between them.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventional Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: struggle

options.name: B
options.content: struggled

options.name: C
options.content: had struggled

options.name: D
options.content: were struggling

questions.correct: struggle

questions.article: A recipient of the Nobel Prize in Chemistry and the Albert Einstein World Award of Science, ______ known as femtochemistry when he devised an optical spectroscopy technique that allowed researchers to study ultrafast chemical reactions occurring within molecules.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: the limits of measurability were expanded by chemist Ahmed Z who introduced a new scientific discipline

options.name: B
options.content: chemist Ahmed Zewail expanded the limits of measurability and introduced a new scientific discipline

options.name: C
options.content: the introduction of a new scientific discipline by chemist Ahmed Zewail led to the expansion of the limits of measurability

options.name: D
options.content: the result of chemist Ahmed Zewail's expansion of the limits of measurability was the introduction of a new scientific discipline

questions.correct: chemist Ahmed Zewail expanded the limits of measurability and introduced a new scientific discipline

questions.article: “Coalition” is the term for a group of male lions, and across the Greater Kruger National Park in South Africa, many coalitions vie for territory. Between 2006 and 2012, the lions of the Mapogo ______ including Rasta, Pretty Boy, and Makhulu—thrived within a part of the park called the Sabi Sands.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: coalition—

options.name: B
options.content: coalition;

options.name: C
options.content: coalition

options.name: D
options.content: coalition,

questions.correct: coalition—

questions.article: Recognized as a National Heritage Area by the United States Congress in 2000, the Wheeling National Heritage Area ______ a region of West Virginia that has long been known for its unique natural, cultural, and historical attributes.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the convention of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: had been

options.name: B
options.content: was

options.name: C
options.content: is

options.name: D
options.content: will have been

questions.correct: is

questions.article: Several advantages—the ability to react strongly with chip components, to avoid interference from other waves, and to be confined within tiny circuits— ________ acoustic waves as a promising alternative to electrical waves for transmitting data on computer chips; as a result, researchers are invested in developing more acoustic wave-based chips.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the convention of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: have positioned

options.name: B
options.content: having positioned

options.name: C
options.content: by positioning

options.name: D
options.content: positioning

questions.correct: have positioned

questions.article: Like much scientific research, a noted 2020 study of diabolical ironclad beetles published in Nature reflects the combined efforts and expertise of multiple ______ Jesus Rivera is listed first, Maryam Sadat Hosseini, David Restrepo, and other coauthors also made important contributions to the study.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the convention of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: researchers;

options.name: B
options.content: researchers, while

options.name: C
options.content: researchers.

options.name: D
options.content: researchers: while

questions.correct: researchers: while

questions.article: Broadcasting from the Umatilla Indian Reservation in Oregon, the Native-run radio station KCUW-LP 104.3 FM serves its local Umatilla-speaking community in several ways. ______ it broadcasts local news and music and also hosts programming in the Umatilla language.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: For instance,

options.name: B
options.content: As a result,

options.name: C
options.content: In the end,

options.name: D
options.content: By contrast,

questions.correct: For instance,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Bucky is the nickname of a dinosaur fossil specimen from the Late Cretaceous period.
  • The Late Cretaceous period ended more than 65 million years ago.
  • Bucky is a member of the genus Tyrannosaurus.
  • Bucky is housed at the Children's Museum of Indianapolis.
  • The Children's Museum of Indianapolis is in Indianapolis, Indiana.
questions.question: The student wants to identify the institution in which Bucky is housed. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Bucky is the nickname of a dinosaur fossil specimen belonging to the genus Tyrannosaurus.

options.name: B
options.content: The Tyrannosaurus fossil specimen Bucky lived more than 65 million years ago, in the Late Cretaceous period.

options.name: C
options.content: Indianapolis, Indiana, is home to a Tyrannosaurus fossil specimen nicknamed Bucky.

options.name: D
options.content: Bucky is housed at the Children's Museum of Indianapolis in Indianapolis, Indiana.

questions.correct: Bucky is housed at the Children's Museum of Indianapolis in Indianapolis, Indiana.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • A supercontinent is a single landmass made up of most or all of Earth's continents.
  • Over time, continents merge together to form supercontinents, which then break apart.
  • This process is believed to take hundreds of millions of years and is known as the supercontinent cycle.
  • Kenorland and Pangaea were supercontinents.
  • Kenorland formed about 2.6 billion years ago.
  • Pangaea formed about 300 million years ago.
questions.question: The student wants to correct a misunderstanding that Pangaea formed before Kenorland. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Forming and breaking apart over hundreds of millions of years, supercontinents are made up of most or all of Earth's continents.

options.name: B
options.content: Kenorland formed about 2.6 billion years ago, long before Pangaea's formation about 300 million years ago.

options.name: C
options.content: Pangaea and Kenorland formed at different times in Earth's history.

options.name: D
options.content: Kenorland and Pangaea were both supercontinents, single landmasses made up of most or all of the Earth's continents.

questions.correct: Kenorland formed about 2.6 billion years ago, long before Pangaea's formation about 300 million years ago.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • A merchant ship is any ship hired to carry cargo or passengers.
  • A ship's carrying capacity is also known as its deadweight tonnage (DWT).
  • In 2021, there were a total of 201 merchant ships registered in Belgium.
  • The combined DWT of these ships was 9.6 million tons.
questions.question: The student wants to identify the combined carrying capacity of Belgium's merchant ships in 2021. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: In 2021, Belgium had 201 merchant ships hired to carry cargo or passengers.

options.name: B
options.content: The carrying capacity of a merchant ship is also known as its deadweight tonnage.

options.name: C
options.content: The combined carrying capacity of Belgium's merchant ships was 9.6 million tons in 2021.

options.name: D
options.content: There were a total of 201 merchant ships (ships hired to carry cargo or passengers) registered in Belgium in 2021.

questions.correct: The combined carrying capacity of Belgium's merchant ships was 9.6 million tons in 2021.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The United States has designated more than 500 areas National Wildlife Refuges (NWRs).
  • Some NWRs were established specifically to protect endangered species.
  • The Mason Neck NWR is a 2,276-acre area in Virginia, on the Atlantic coast.
  • It was established to protect the endangered bald eagle.
  • The Coachella Valley NWR is a 3,592-acre area in California, on the Pacific coast.
  • It was established to protect the endangered Coachella Valley fringe-toed lizard.
questions.question: The student wants to contrast the two NWRs. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Some NWRs were established specifically to protect endangered species such as the Coachella Valley fringe-toed lizard.

options.name: B
options.content: The US has designated more than 500 areas NWRs, including the Mason Neck NWR in Virginia.

options.name: C
options.content: While the Mason Neck NWR is in Virginia, on the Atlantic coast, the Coachella Valley NWR is in California, on the Pacific coast.

options.name: D
options.content: Both the Mason Neck NWR and the Coachella Valley NWR were established to protect endangered species.

questions.correct: While the Mason Neck NWR is in Virginia, on the Atlantic coast, the Coachella Valley NWR is in California, on the Pacific coast.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The French Republican calendar was developed during the French Revolution.
  • It had twelve months divided into three weeks of ten days each, followed by five supplemental days.
  • Each day was named after a plant, animal, agricultural tool, or mineral as a way of honoring an aspect of rural life.
  • Prairial is the ninth month of the French Republican calendar.
  • The third day of Prairial is named Trefle, which means “clover.”
questions.question: The student wants to explain why a day in the French Republican calendar's month of Prairial was named Trefle. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: The month of Prairial was divided into three weeks of ten days each, and one of t se days was named Trefle.

options.name: B
options.content: Developed during the French Revolution, the French Republican calendar has twelve months, including Prairial.

options.name: C
options.content: Each day of the French Republican calendar year honors an aspect of rural life, which is why the third of Prairial is named after a plant, the clover.

options.name: D
options.content: When the French Republican calendar was developed during the French Revolution, the third of Prairial was named Trefle.

questions.correct: Each day of the French Republican calendar year honors an aspect of rural life, which is why the third of Prairial is named after a plant, the clover.
